DataElement.preferredName: Peripheral Blood Stem Cell CD34+ Cell Harvest CD34 Cell Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value to represent the number of CD34 cells harvested for peripheral blood stem cell transplantation.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Peripheral Blood Stem Cell CD34+ Cell Harvest Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to a peripheral blood stem CD34+ cell harvest performed.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Immature cells found circulating in the bloodstream. New blood cells develop from peripheral stem cells.:No value exists.:Harvest; remove from a culture or a living or dead body, as for the purposes of transplantation.

Concepts.definition: An immature (progenitor) cell circulating in the peripheral blood.  It has the capacity for replication and differentiation to mature blood cells.
Remove from a culture or a living or dead body, as for the purposes of transplantation.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Harvest CD34 Cell Value
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Similar to bone marrow transplantation, peripheral stem cell transplantation is a method of replacing the blood-forming cells lost due to high-dose chemotherapy, and possibly radiation therapy, used to destroy leukemia cells. Certain immature circulating blood cells, similar to stem cells in the bone marrow, are removed before treatment. The cells are then given to the patient after treatment to help the bone marrow recover and continue producing healthy blood cells.  Transplantation may be autologous (the patient's own blood cells are used), allogeneic (blood cells are donated by someone else), or syngeneic (blood cells are donated by an identical twin).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: CD34 Antigen Cell Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation Value
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A protein found on the surface of some bone marrow and blood cells.:The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.:Similar to bone marrow transplantation, peripheral stem cell transplantation is a method of replacing the blood-forming cells lost due to high-dose chemotherapy, and possibly radiation therapy, used to destroy leukemia cells. Certain immature circulating blood cells, similar to stem cells in the bone marrow, are removed before treatment. The cells are then given to the patient after treatment to help the bone marrow recover and continue producing healthy blood cells.  Transplantation may be autologous (the patient's own blood cells are used), allogeneic (blood cells are donated by someone else), or syngeneic (blood cells are donated by an identical twin).:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: Hematopoietic progenitor cell antigen CD34 (385 aa, ~41 kDa) is encoded by the human CD34 gene. This protein plays a role in cell-cell adhesion and may have a role in leukocyte migration.
The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.

A method of hematopoietic reconstitution utilizing stem cells harvested from the circulating blood of a patient or donor. Peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (PBSCT) is used for the treatment of certain blood disorders, following partial or complete bone marrow ablation, or following high dose chemotherapy or radiation treatment for cancer. Immature circulating blood cells, similar to stem cells in the bone marrow, are removed before treatment. The cells are then given to the patient after treatment to help the bone marrow recover and continue producing healthy blood cells. Transplantation may be autologous (the patient's own blood cells are used), allogeneic (blood cells are donated by someone else), or syngeneic (blood cells are donated by an identical twin).
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.
